moves.1. d4: Once again, a never-say-die attitude pays dividends :-)  My last game in the 2009 Championship.  When we started this game jklarl's rating was way higher than mine, so I started with the strategic 1. d4, as I feel that slower styled games give me a better chance against better players.  Crash bang wallop open games tend to end up with me being the walloped one.
moves.1... Nf6 2. c4 g6 3. Nc3 d5: The Grunfeld.  A good, counter-attacking response by Black.
moves.4. cxd5 Nxd5 5. Nxd5: ? Not sure why I diverted from the book's 5. e4 Nxc3 here.  This does not work out well.
moves.9... cxd4 10. exd4 Qxa2 11. Bc4 Qxb2: Black has two remote passed pawns for nothing.  All he needs to do is swap off all the pieces and Bob's your uncle.
moves.12. O-O Nc6 13. Rc2 Qb6 14. Be3: Everything is centring around my isolani on d4.
moves.17... Qc7: Gets the Q off the same file as my rook and prepares to let a rook onto the d-file.
moves.18. Rfd1: I try to turn my isolani into a battering ram.
moves.18... e6 19. Qe4: I don't remember my actual thinking behind this move but I suspect it was so that when I advance the d-pawn, the Q won't be attacked by ...Ne5.
moves.19... Rfd8 20. d5 Ne5 21. Be2 exd5 22. R: The swaps have helped Black again.  Advancing my pawn may not have been so bright.
moves.25... Qc2 26. Bf3 g5 27. Qg3: ... if 27. Qxg5 Nxf3+ and White's rook falls
moves.28. Bxf4 Nxf3+ 29. Qxf3 gxf4 30. Rd7: activating the rook and freeing the Q from defending it.  White could have resigned at this point ... but hope springs eternal :-)
moves.30... Qc1+ 31. Kh2 Qc6 32. Qg4 Qf6 33. R: a welcome pawn :-)  Only a bishop down now ...
moves.33... a5 34. Qf3: hoping for the swindle Rxg7+ followed by Qxa8
moves.34... Rf8 35. Ra7: Nimzo would have been proud of this move: the monster must be contained!
moves.35... Qe5 36. Ra6: White had to move but had nothing constructive.  This move retains the control of the a-pawn and cedes nothing else.
moves.37... h5 38. Rb7: harassing Black's Q for want of anything better to do.  White's plan at this point is merely to hassle Black as much as he can.
moves.38... Qc5 39. Rd7: threatening to fork the wing pawns with Rd5, Q moves
moves.39... Rf5 40. Rd2: defending f2 so that the Q can move
moves.41. Qa8+ Kh7 42. Qxa4 Kg6 43. Qe8+ Kh6 4: ! piling up the pressure on Black's h-pawn, with potential mate threats to follow.
moves.47... Qxd5: ?! Black returns extra material but did he have anything better?
moves.48. Qxf6+: ?! not realising the strength of my previous threat, I thought Black was up to something devious and decided to keep Queens on, accepting Rook and Bishop, rather than Q, as I didn't fancy the complications of Q vs R&B.  This worked out rather well but I think I should have been more materialistic at this stage.
moves.48... Kh7 49. Qxf8 f3: ?  Gives up a pawn for nothing.  Now I'm suddenly winning!
moves.50. Qxf3 Qxf3: Compounds the error.  Black's only hope rested with keeping Queens on board.
moves.52. f4: providing him with an escape hatch
moves.52... Kh6 53. Kg2 Kg6 54. Kf3 Kf5: Black seizes the opposition but it's no use when my pawns control g4, g5 and e5
moves.55. Ke3: and Black resigned because his King gets pushed backwards and White queens a pawn or two.

gameName: SPEEDTOUCH INTERNATIONAL PLAYERS CHAMPIONSHIP 2009 - Never Say Die
